migration drivers we see a number of business different business drivers for companies who are looking to migrate to
the cloud first they're looking for an increase in their business agility some of our customers are creating business
cases where they believe that their workforce can be 30 to 70% more productive and deliver features much
faster as a result of migrating their skills and applications to the cloud we also see a lot of data data center
consolidation projects especially in companies that have been active with acquisitions or have experienced
infrastructure sprawl over the years and and of course any cost conscious organization is always looking for ways
to improve the bottom line by reducing their costs and while there are a lot of reasons enterprises are motivated to
migrate their legacy systems to the cloud oftentimes comprising of tens of thousands servers or even dozen dozens
of applications and data centers they're asking a lot of questions about how they can do it quickly so that gets us to
potential barriers to cloud adoption when customers are ready to us to adopt and start migrating AWS they could run
in any one of these challenges I'll talk about upfront expenses for example it's important to remember that in cloud
computing it's built around a pay-as-you-go pricing model so you're only paying for what you use and there
are options in the compute category for instance like reserved instances or spot instances that can really provide you
with a significant discount if your if your workloads fall into that model fear of downtime during migration this is
really where you need to think about how you're going to build a test plan around your migration you're going to want to try and build that confidence level but
you also need to take advantage of tools in this space and potentially even partners to assist in the migration to
actually shorten those down time windows to eliminate that fear of downtime lack of cloud expertise we're going to talk
